awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Simulating Crack Propagation in Steel Structures Under Ultra-Low Cycle Fatigue and Low-Triaxiality Loading from Earthquakes and Other Hazards
awd_abstract_narration:
Buildings, tunnels, utility pipelines, and other structures constructed of steel are critical components of the nation's civil infrastructure. As experienced during previous disasters, such as in the 1994 Northridge, California earthquake, steel structures are vulnerable to collapse or failure, resulting in loss of life and property. Cracking (i.e., fracture) in critical parts of these structures is often the reason for their failure.  Consequently, designing structures to minimize the risk of fracture is critical for infrastructure safety and operability. However, methods to predict the growth of cracks are not well-developed, especially when fractures occur during severe shaking caused by earthquakes or other extreme loads. By combining expertise from structural engineering, materials science, and computational mechanics, the objectives of this research are to: (1) create new models and computational technologies to accurately simulate this type of cracking, and (2) integrate these models into the design process for civil infrastructure. Undergraduate and graduate students will actively participate in this research.  The new knowledge, models, and software products from this research, through transfer to practitioners, will improve the safety and economy of buildings and other civil infrastructure, benefiting the U.S. society and economy. 

Nonlinear analysis is an essential technology for the modern performance-based design and construction of buildings and civil infrastructure that are more resilient to earthquakes and other extreme hazards. This research addresses a significant limitation of nonlinear analysis as it pertains to simulating crack propagation in steel structures, under two important situations: (1) ultra-low cycle fatigue (ULCF) loading, which is characterized by few (<20) cycles of large strain amplitude that can occur under earthquakes and other hazards, and (2) low-stress triaxiality, which often occurs with ULCF loading in shear bands or at protruding corners of structural elements. This research will address these challenges through fundamental theoretical model development (a new damage mechanics based constitutive model for ULCF and low-triaxiality), computational methods synthesis, numerical implementation, laboratory testing, and calibration and validation of model implementations. The work will combine models for ductile crack initiation with computational techniques, resulting in validated approaches for simulating crack propagation under ULCF and low-triaxiality. The project will culminate in a campaign to facilitate adoption of the fracture simulation techniques into engineering research and practice, including standardization of simulation and calibration methods required for their realization, and development of open source software. These research products and their adoption into engineering practice will enhance safety and performance of the built environment.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Steel structures, which comprise a critical component of the nation?s buildings and civil infrastructure, must be designed to safely resist failure or collapse due to material yielding, buckling, and fracture.  Fracture (or cracking) in highly stressed regions of the steel structures is of primary concern since experience has shown it to often be a critical mode of failure. Prominent recent examples of fracture in steel structures include the 2019 incident that closed the new TransBay transportation terminal in San Francisco, the tragic 2007 collapse of the I-35 bridge in Minneapolis, and welded connection fractures in buildings during the 1994 Northridge earthquake. Consequently, predicting cracking (and designing structures to resist it) is critical for infrastructure safety and operability. However, methods to predict the growth of cracks are not well-developed, especially when the cracks occur during dynamic shaking that can occur when structures are subjected to strong earthquakes. By combining expertise from structural engineering, materials science, and computational mechanics, this project has created a new method that enables accurate computer simulation of this type of cracking. The newly developed method has been implemented into a free and open-source software program, such that other researchers and engineering professionals can apply the simulation technology to assess the performance of buildings, ultimately leading to safer and economical design of both new structures and retrofit of existing structures. The findings and software products from this research will improve the safety and economy of steel-framed buildings and other infrastructure. A summary of the outcomes is now provided, with respect to the intellectual merits and broader impacts.

Outcomes with respect to intellectual merits:

  • A new mathematical model for computationally simulating the initiation and propagation of cracking of steel structures under earthquake and similar loading types was developed. The model can be applied to a range of structural components with differing geometries and loading conditions (e.g., induced by gravity, earthquake, or wind loading). The method is implemented using state-of-the-art finite element simulation technologies and is not sensitive to what is known as finite-element ?mesh-dependence?, where a user?s choice of how finely a structural component is subdivided can adversely affect the accuracy of results. This is a major step forward over existing methods to simulate crack growth.
  • This framework was implemented into a free and open-source software platform, such that it may be conveniently applied to assess the performance of buildings and other structures,  ultimately leading to safer and economic designs as well as retrofits.
  • Laboratory tests were conducted on structural steel materials to provide data against which the proposed computer simulations could be validated. Comparisons between observations of the physical tests and computer simulations confirmed the accuracy of the proposed computer models to predict both the initiation and growth of cracks under conditions that are representative of the loads imposed on structures by earthquakes and other hazardous events.
  • The work was disseminated to the scientific community and the public through journal articles as well as conference presentations.

Outcomes with respect to broader impacts:

  • The work has resulted in an improved technology to evaluate and design building and civil engineering infrastructure to safely resist fracture.  This technology will enable engineers to design more reliable and economic structures, benefiting the nation?s society and economy. These research products and their adoption into engineering practice will greatly enhance safety and performance of the built environment. 
  • This work has resulted in the training of four doctoral students.  Of these, one is employed at Sandia National Laboratories, one is now a tenure track faculty member at the North Carolina State University, and one is employed by the steel industry.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2022
Modified by: Gregory G Deierlein
por.por_txt_cntn:
Steel structures, which comprise a critical component of the nation?s buildings and civil infrastructure, must be designed to safely resist failure or collapse due to material yielding, buckling, and fracture.  Fracture (or cracking) in highly stressed regions of the steel structures is of primary concern since experience has shown it to often be a critical mode of failure. Prominent recent examples of fracture in steel structures include the 2019 incident that closed the new TransBay transportation terminal in San Francisco, the tragic 2007 collapse of the I-35 bridge in Minneapolis, and welded connection fractures in buildings during the 1994 Northridge earthquake. Consequently, predicting cracking (and designing structures to resist it) is critical for infrastructure safety and operability. However, methods to predict the growth of cracks are not well-developed, especially when the cracks occur during dynamic shaking that can occur when structures are subjected to strong earthquakes. By combining expertise from structural engineering, materials science, and computational mechanics, this project has created a new method that enables accurate computer simulation of this type of cracking. The newly developed method has been implemented into a free and open-source software program, such that other researchers and engineering professionals can apply the simulation technology to assess the performance of buildings, ultimately leading to safer and economical design of both new structures and retrofit of existing structures. The findings and software products from this research will improve the safety and economy of steel-framed buildings and other infrastructure. A summary of the outcomes is now provided, with respect to the intellectual merits and broader impacts.

Outcomes with respect to intellectual merits:

A new mathematical model for computationally simulating the initiation and propagation of cracking of steel structures under earthquake and similar loading types was developed. The model can be applied to a range of structural components with differing geometries and loading conditions (e.g., induced by gravity, earthquake, or wind loading). The method is implemented using state-of-the-art finite element simulation technologies and is not sensitive to what is known as finite-element ?mesh-dependence?, where a user?s choice of how finely a structural component is subdivided can adversely affect the accuracy of results. This is a major step forward over existing methods to simulate crack growth.
This framework was implemented into a free and open-source software platform, such that it may be conveniently applied to assess the performance of buildings and other structures,  ultimately leading to safer and economic designs as well as retrofits.
Laboratory tests were conducted on structural steel materials to provide data against which the proposed computer simulations could be validated. Comparisons between observations of the physical tests and computer simulations confirmed the accuracy of the proposed computer models to predict both the initiation and growth of cracks under conditions that are representative of the loads imposed on structures by earthquakes and other hazardous events.
The work was disseminated to the scientific community and the public through journal articles as well as conference presentations. 


Outcomes with respect to broader impacts:

The work has resulted in an improved technology to evaluate and design building and civil engineering infrastructure to safely resist fracture.  This technology will enable engineers to design more reliable and economic structures, benefiting the nation?s society and economy. These research products and their adoption into engineering practice will greatly enhance safety and performance of the built environment.  
This work has resulted in the training of four doctoral students.  Of these, one is employed at Sandia National Laboratories, one is now a tenure track faculty member at the North Carolina State University, and one is employed by the steel industry.
